title: On the Pauli Spectrum of ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢â°
abstract:
Abstract
The circuit class ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} was introduced by Moore (1999) as a model for constant depth quantum circuits where the gate set includes many-qubit Toffoli gates. Proving lower bounds against such circuits is a longstanding challenge in quantum circuit complexity; in particular, showing that polynomial-size ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} cannot compute the parity function has remained an open question for over 20 years.
In this work, we identify a notion of the Pauli spectrum of ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits, which can be viewed as the quantum analogue of the Fourier spectrum of classical ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC}^{0} circuits. We conjecture that the Pauli spectrum of ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits satisfies low-degree concentration, in analogy to the famous Linial, Nisan, Mansour theorem on the low-degree Fourier concentration of ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{AC}^{0} circuits. If true, this conjecture immediately implies that polynomial-size ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits cannot compute parity.
We prove this conjecture for
the class of depth-dğ‘‘d, polynomial-size ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits with at most nOâ€‹(1/d)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚1ğ‘‘n^{O(1/d)} auxiliary qubits. We obtain new circuit lower bounds and learning results as applications: this class of circuits cannot correctly compute


â€¢

the nğ‘›n-bit parity function on more than (12+2âˆ’Î©â€‹(n1/d))12superscript2Î©superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘‘(\frac{1}{2}+2^{-\Omega(n^{1/d})})-fraction of inputs, and



â€¢

the nğ‘›n-bit majority function on more than (12+Oâ€‹(nâˆ’1/4))12ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›14(\frac{1}{2}+O(n^{-1/4}))-fraction of inputs.



Additionally we show that this class of ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits with limited auxiliary qubits can be learned with quasipolynomial sample complexity, giving the first learning result for ğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0superscriptğ–°ğ– ğ–¢0\mathsf{QAC}^{0} circuits.
More broadly, our results add evidence that â€œPauli-analyticâ€ techniques can be a powerful tool in studying quantum circuits.
